title.narrative: Yes I Do - Zambia

description.narrative: In Zambia KIT is responsible for conducting research on the root causes of child marriage & teenage pregnancies, testing the assumptions of the TOC, and for measuring effectiveness of strategic interventions on child marriages & teenage pregnancies. This means that KIT is responsible for the base and end line studies, the midline and the operational research. KIT closely collaborates with local researchers and capacitates local research teams on mixed methods research and knowledge management. The research has the aim to test the underlying assumptions of the programme’s theory of change, to measure the effectiveness of the interventions introduced by the programme and to look into the interrelations between child marriage and teenage pregnancy and the interventions that address these in Zambia. The research will contribute to optimization of the Yes I Do intervention strategies and provide context specific knowledge for advocacy and policy purposes, in order to move towards a situation in which adolescent girls can decide if, when and whom to marry and if, when and with whom to have children. Furthermore KIT will lead on the validation and dissemination of research outcomes, and analysing country specific Monitoring & Evaluation data for lessons learned and measuring outcomes and impact of the Yes I do Alliance in Zambia.

mailing-address.narrative: Mailing address: P.O. Box 95001 1090 HA Amsterdam Visitor address: Mauritskade 63 1092 AD Amsterdam The Netherlands

title.narrative: Operational Research - Studies

description.narrative: local research partners contributed to the output

title.narrative: Number of operational research studies conducted

description.narrative: the total number of studies that were conducted on specific topics

comment.narrative: Two studies were conducted in Zambia. One mixed-methods operational study, the baseline of the Champions of Change project (on gender equality and rights) implemented by Plan Zambia. Furthermore, a small scale qualitative study on initiation ceremonies was conducted. Both studies took place in Chadiza district. Data collection took place between 23 November and 8 December, analysis took place in December 2017 and January 2018.
